In fact, many of them are not metabolized at all, which means they pass through the body unchanged—or worse, they interact with biological systems in ways we're only beginning to understand.

Aspartame, for example, breaks down into phenylalanine, aspartic acid, and methanol. While small amounts of these may not be harmful, regular and high-dose consumption has been linked to neurological effects. Despite being marketed as "sugar-free" and "calorie-free," they may actually contribute to insulin resistance and weight gain. Moreover, there's growing evidence that artificial sweeteners may impact the liver and kidneys. They've been associated with increased oxidative stress and inflammation, which are underlying factors in many chronic diseases.

The bottom line is that while regulatory agencies have approved these substances, the long-term safety of regular consumption is far from proven. In fact, many countries and health experts are re-evaluating their stance in light of new scientific findings. If you're looking to protect your health, it's wise to err on the side of caution and limit or eliminate artificial sweeteners from your diet.
